any_of is basically std::disjunction and all_of is std::conjunction. Maybe makes sense to name them accordingly, and then also take the "official" implementation from here to make sure it behaves correctly and we didn't miss any corner cases.

Note: std::conjunction and std::disjunction have a slightly different interface because they use types instead of bool template arguments, but that actually makes it more versatile. You can still use it with bools together with std::bool_constant if you need to.

template<bool... args> using any_of = std::disjunction<std::bool_constant<args>...>;
